verses.text: Now Jericho was tightly shut up because of the children of Israel; no one went out and no one came in.
verses.comment: “Tightly shut up” closely follows the Hebrew phrase meaning 'closed up, secured.'

verses.text: The LORD said to Joshua, 'See, I have given Jericho into your hand, with its king and its mighty men of valor.'
verses.comment: The Hebrew verb tense suggests completed action, i.e., 'I have given.'

verses.text: You shall march around the city, all the men of war going around the city once. Do this for six days.
verses.comment: Explicit subject added for clarity: 'all the men of war.'

verses.text: Seven priests shall carry seven trumpets of rams’ horns before the ark. On the seventh day, you shall march around the city seven times, and the priests shall blow the trumpets.
verses.comment: ‘Rams’ horns’ translates ‘shofarot,’ the Hebrew term for trumpet made from a ram’s horn.

verses.text: When they make a long blast with the ram’s horn, and when you hear the sound of the trumpet, all the people shall shout with a great shout. The wall of the city will fall down flat, and the people shall go up, every man straight before him.
verses.comment: ‘Fall down flat’ reflects the idiomatic Hebrew meaning.

verses.text: So Joshua the son of Nun called the priests and said to them, 'Take up the ark of the covenant, and let seven priests carry seven trumpets of rams’ horns before the ark of the LORD.'
verses.comment: Faithful to the sequence and roles described in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And he said to the people, 'Go forward! March around the city, and let the armed men pass on before the ark of the LORD.'
verses.comment: ‘Armed men’ translates the Hebrew ‘halutsim,’ meaning ‘the equipped/armed ones.’

verses.text: And as Joshua had commanded the people, the seven priests carrying the seven trumpets of rams’ horns before the LORD went forward and blew the trumpets, and the ark of the covenant of the LORD followed them.
verses.comment: Follows word order of Hebrew for clarity.

verses.text: The armed men went before the priests blowing the trumpets, and the rear guard came after the ark, while the trumpets kept blowing.
verses.comment: ‘Rear guard’ translates ‘ha’asef,’ the Hebrew for ‘gatherer/one who assembles.'

verses.text: But Joshua commanded the people, 'You shall not shout or make your voice heard, nor shall any word go out of your mouth, until the day I tell you to shout. Then you shall shout.'
verses.comment: Maintains the negative commands as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So he caused the ark of the LORD to circle the city, going around it once. Then they came into the camp and spent the night in the camp.
verses.comment: 'Circle' reflects the Hebrew repetition structure.

verses.text: And Joshua rose early in the morning, and the priests took up the ark of the LORD.
verses.comment: Standard phrase for readiness in Joshua.

verses.text: The seven priests carrying the seven trumpets of rams’ horns before the ark of the LORD went on continually, and blew with the trumpets. The armed men went before them, and the rear guard followed the ark of the LORD, while the trumpets blew continually.
verses.comment: ‘Continually’ is a literal rendering of the Hebrew 'holekh halok.'

verses.text: And the second day they marched around the city once and returned to the camp. They did this for six days.
verses.comment: Numbers in English clarified for readability.

verses.text: On the seventh day, they rose early, at the break of dawn, and marched around the city in the same way seven times. It was only on that day that they marched around the city seven times.
verses.comment: ‘At the break of dawn’ translates ‘alot hashachar,’ a precise Hebrew time expression.

verses.text: On the seventh time, when the priests had blown the trumpets, Joshua said to the people, 'Shout, for the LORD has given you the city!'
verses.comment: Present perfect 'has given' reflects the Hebrew structure.

verses.text: And the city and all that is within it shall be devoted to the LORD for destruction. Only Rahab the prostitute, and all who are with her in the house, shall live, because she hid the messengers whom we sent.
verses.comment: ‘Devoted...for destruction’ renders ‘herem,’ a technical term in Hebrew.

verses.text: But as for you, keep yourselves from the things devoted to destruction, lest when you have devoted them, you take any of the devoted things and make the camp of Israel a thing for destruction, and bring trouble upon it.
verses.comment: Repeated 'devoted/devoted things' follows Hebrew repetition for emphasis.

verses.text: But all the silver and gold, and vessels of bronze and iron, are holy to the LORD; they shall go into the treasury of the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Treasury' translates the Hebrew 'otsar', meaning storehouse for holy objects.

verses.text: So the people shouted, and the trumpets were blown. As soon as the people heard the sound of the trumpet, the people shouted with a great shout, and the wall fell down flat. So the people went up into the city, every man straight before him, and they captured the city.
verses.comment: Maintains the sequence and parallel Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: Then they utterly destroyed all that was in the city, both man and woman, young and old, ox, sheep, and donkey, with the edge of the sword.
verses.comment: ‘Utterly destroyed’ follows the sense of ‘herem’ again here.

verses.text: But Joshua said to the two men who had spied out the land, 'Go into the prostitute’s house and bring out from there the woman and all who belong to her, as you swore to her.'
verses.comment: ‘Spied out’ translates the direct Hebrew verb for scouting.

verses.text: So the young men who had been spies went in and brought out Rahab, her father and mother, her brothers, and all who belonged to her. They brought out all her relatives and set them outside the camp of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Set them outside the camp’ retains the Hebrew idiom for temporary separation for purification.

verses.text: And they burned the city with fire, and all that was in it. Only the silver and gold and the vessels of bronze and of iron they put into the treasury of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Treasury of the house of the LORD’ follows typical temple terminology.

verses.text: But Rahab the prostitute, her father's household, and all who belonged to her, Joshua saved alive. She has lived in Israel to this day, because she hid the messengers whom Joshua sent to spy out Jericho.
verses.comment: ‘Saved alive’ is literal translation of Hebrew.

verses.text: Joshua laid an oath on them at that time, saying, 'Cursed before the LORD be the man who rises up and rebuilds this city, Jericho. At the cost of his firstborn he shall lay its foundation, and at the cost of his youngest son he shall set up its gates.'
verses.comment: Curse structure and formula remain literal to Hebrew.

verses.text: So the LORD was with Joshua, and his fame was in all the land.
verses.comment: ‘Was in all the land’ is a literal rendering reflecting effect on the region.
